awd_titl_txt: RUI: Activity-based Mapping of Cellular Cathepsins B and L - An introduction to Chemical Biology in Undergraduate Curriculum
awd_abstract_narration:
With this RUI award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor Sanjai Kumar to investigate the function of two important enzymes found in human cells. A cell is a complex yet highly organized system where thousands of events are coordinated with great precision at any given moment. These processes are elegantly orchestrated by proteins, the main centers of activity of the cell. It is estimated that the total number of proteins in a human cell is between 250,000 to one million. Assigning individual functions to the various proteins is a challenging endeavor, especially since a protein may be active or inactive depending on the status of the cell. This status of a protein is often controlled by a group of enzymes known as proteases. The human genome has the capacity to produce about 550 proteases. How, why, and where these proteases function in the complex cellular environment remains poorly understood.  This project involves examining two closely-related proteases of the cysteine cathepsin family of enzymes; cathepsin B and L. Selective probes are made to target these cathepsins so that their function can be understood.  This research endeavor provides educational opportunities with hands-on research experience to graduate and undergraduate students. The laboratory environment is structured for an enhanced interdisciplinary experience for both undergraduate and graduate students. Additionally, there are outreach activities incorporating research training for students from Queensborough Community College and Bard High School Early College in New York. Special emphasis is given to include students from underrepresented groups in science disciplines, women, and veterans. 

Human cysteine cathepsins comprise a small group of eleven enzymes that are important in maintaining cell homeostasis, growth, differentiation, and survival. One of the main challenges of cathepsin biology is in assigning specific function to individual enzymes in a given cellular context. This is mainly because several functional redundancies and overlapping substrate specificities have been shown to exist in individual cell types. Since newly synthesized cellular cathepsins are subject to post-translational modifications, thereby leading to alteration of their activities (and hence function), specific investigative tools are needed for activity-based interrogation of cellular function in live cells. This project is developing selective tagless activity-based probes (TABPs) of two closely related cysteine cathepsins; cathepsin L and B. The developed TABPs are used in differential and quantitative mapping of cathepsin B and L activities in live pancreatic and neuronal cells. The knowledge gained from these studies significantly advances the functional understanding of cellular processes involving human cathepsin B and L.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RESEARCH FOUNDATION OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Human biology is highly complex and yet very organized at the cellular levels. This organized nature helps us grow, adapt and thrive throughout our development. The biochemical tasks in our cells are elegantly orchestrated by several biomolecules, such as DNA, RNA, and proteins. These biomolecules constantly communicate with each other via specialized signaling networks, much like electrical signals in a complex integrated circuit (IC). Among these, enzymes - mostly proteins - are critically important biological catalyst that carry out numerous biochemical reactions in our cells at appropriate rates. In normal cells, their functions are tightly regulated by specific cellular mechanisms. In disease states, however, their function becomes highly erratic and often unknown. Well-organized documentation of enzyme function from various families is therefore essential for our knowledge, scientific advancement, and health. Human Cathepsin B and L are two protein-degrading enzymes from the cysteine cathepsin family whose functions are poorly understood in the context of specific cell types. In addition, when their behavior is erratic, they promote several life-threatening diseases, including cancer and metabolic and immune disorders. Appropriate scientific methodologies must be developed and utilized so that their functions in relevant cellular contexts can be delineated with enhanced precision. To facilitate this, we developed one of a kind, clickable and tagless specific activity-based chemical probes that can be utilized to document the function of both human cathepsin L and B in cells from distinct cellular origins. It is anticipated that these discoveries will significantly advance our current understanding of biology mediated by cysteine cathepsin enzymes. The research knowledge generated from these studies have been disseminated to general public via conference presentations and publications in peer-reviewed journals where several undergraduate students are co-authors. The insight gained from this project is anticipated to significantly benefit our society, such as in development of highly personalized medicines with minimal side effects.  

            Development of a diverse robust young work force in Science Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) is quintessential to combat future challenges and thus remains our nation’s top priority. One of the key objectives of this NSF RUI grant was to inspire and develop STEM-ready students through rigorous research training and education. This task was achieved through a systematic recruitment of motivated student participants from Queens College, Bard High School Early College Queens, and local high schools. The recruitment efforts focused on students from a diverse academic and socioeconomic backgrounds, and the outreach activities spanned during the academic year as well as in summer months. The participating students were mentored in the interdisciplinary educational and research activities. They (a) learned how to embark upon a scientific problem, plan experiments, and generate and analyze data, (b) gained hands-on research training involving scientific experiments, and (c) presented their scientific findings (via talk or a poster presentation) at local and national conferences. They were also imparted career counseling in STEM discipline. Most participating students in this program have pursued one or more of the following paths: (i) a college degree with the emphasis on a STEM major (e.g. students from BHSECQ and local high schools), (ii) a professional degree in human health sciences (medical/nursing/dental schools), and (iii) a graduate degree. A total of 14 undergraduates, 19 High School students, 5 MA degree student, and a Ph.D. graduate student have directly benefitted from this project activities. They are now part of STEM-ready human resources that are primed to tackle emerging challenges in science, medicine, and sustainability. These well-informed citizens will emerge as future scientists, doctors, engineers and educators - a workforce that is academically and socioeconomically diverse, in accordance with the mission of NSF.

 


Last Modified: 10/12/2021
Modified by: Sanjai K Pathak
